quotes.quote: Know thyself.
quotes.history: Socrates is said to have spoken these words during his defense at trial, as recounted in Plato's dialogues.

quotes.quote: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
quotes.history: Socrates is said to have spoken these words to a young man who claimed to have knowledge, as recounted in Plato's dialogues.

quotes.quote: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.
quotes.history: Seneca wrote this in a letter to his friend Lucilius, advising him on how to live a fulfilling life.

quotes.quote: Happiness is not something ready made. It comes from your own actions.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, where he argues that happiness is not a state but an activity.

quotes.quote: A hero is born among a hundred, a wise man is found among a thousand, but an accomplished one might not be found even among a hundred thousand men.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato's Republic, where he discusses the qualities of a good ruler.

quotes.quote: Excess of anything is a vice.
quotes.history: This is a common saying in Greek culture, reflecting the value of moderation.

quotes.quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato's Apology, where Socrates argues that self-reflection is essential to a meaningful life.

quotes.quote: Good people do not need laws to tell them to act responsibly, while bad people will find a way around the laws.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato's Republic, where he discusses the ideal society and the role of laws in promoting justice.

quotes.quote: Courage is the first of human qualities because it is the quality which guarantees the others.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, where he discusses the importance of courage in the development of virtue.

quotes.quote: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato's Republic, where he discusses the qualities of a good ruler and the importance of using power responsibly.

quotes.quote: The more you know, the more you realize you know nothing.
quotes.history: This quote is attributed to Socrates, although there is no record of him saying it in the surviving texts.

quotes.quote: No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it's not the same river and he's not the same man.
quotes.history: This quote is from Heraclitus, who believed that everything is constantly changing and that we can never step in the same river twice.

quotes.quote: There is nothing permanent except change.
quotes.history: This quote is also from Heraclitus, emphasizing the transient nature of everything in the universe.

quotes.quote: Wise men speak because they have something to say; fools because they have to say something.
quotes.history: This quote is attributed to Plato, although there is no record of him saying it in the surviving texts.

quotes.quote: The only constant in life is change.
quotes.history: This is a variation of a quote from Heraclitus, emphasizing the impermanence of everything in the universe.

quotes.quote: The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new.
quotes.history: While this quote is often attributed to Socrates, there is no record of him saying it in the surviving texts.

quotes.quote: Everything in excess is opposed to nature.
quotes.history: This quote is from Hippocrates, the father of modern medicine, who believed in the importance of moderation for good health.

quotes.quote: We can easily forgive a child who is afraid of the dark; the real tragedy of life is when men are afraid of the light.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato's Republic, where he discusses the nature of knowledge and the fear of the unknown.

quotes.quote: He who is not a good servant will not be a good master.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Politics, where he discusses the qualities of a good ruler and the importance of serving the common good.

quotes.quote: True knowledge exists in knowing that you know nothing.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed in the importance of questioning everything and recognizing the limitations of one's own knowledge.

quotes.quote: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Metaphysics, where he discusses the importance of critical thinking and intellectual curiosity.

quotes.quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates' Apology, where he defends himself against charges of impiety and corrupting the youth by arguing that his philosophy of self-examination is essential for a meaningful life.

quotes.quote: The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Metaphysics, where he argues that things have essential properties that cannot be reduced to their individual parts.

quotes.quote: Happiness is the meaning and the purpose of life, the whole aim and end of human existence.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, where he discusses the nature of happiness and the importance of cultivating virtues to achieve it.

quotes.quote: The wise man does not expose himself needlessly to danger, since there are few things for which he cares sufficiently; but he is willing, in great crises, to give even his life--knowing that under certain conditions it is not worthwhile to live.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, where he discusses the importance of courage and the risks that wise men are willing to take in defense of their values.

quotes.quote: The first and greatest victory is to conquer yourself.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato's Republic, where he discusses the importance of self-control and the need to overcome one's own passions and desires in order to achieve true happiness.

quotes.quote: Excellence is never an accident. It is always the result of high intention, sincere effort, and intelligent execution; it represents the wise choice of many alternatives.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, where he argues that excellence is a matter of deliberate practice and the cultivation of good habits over time.

quotes.quote: At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice he is the worst.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Politics, where he argues that human beings are social creatures who need laws and institutions to regulate their behavior and promote the common good.

quotes.quote: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that questioning one's assumptions and recognizing one's limitations was the key to true wisdom.

quotes.quote: It is not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
quotes.history: This quote is from Epictetus, a Greek philosopher who emphasized the importance of focusing on what is within our control and maintaining a calm and rational attitude in the face of adversity.

quotes.quote: To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment.
quotes.history: This quote is often attributed to Ralph Waldo Emerson, but is believed to have been inspired by the ancient Greek philosopher Heraclitus, who argued that everything is constantly in flux and that one's true identity can only be found through self-exploration and reflection.

quotes.quote: There is only one good, knowledge, and one evil, ignorance.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that the pursuit of knowledge and wisdom was the key to a virtuous life.

quotes.quote: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, where he argues that excellence is a matter of habituation and the cultivation of good practices over time.

quotes.quote: The more you know, the more you realize you don't know.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed in the importance of questioning everything and recognizing the limitations of one's own knowledge.

quotes.quote: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, who believed that material possessions and wealth were ultimately meaningless compared to the pursuit of knowledge and wisdom.

quotes.quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that questioning one's beliefs and examining one's own life was essential to living a meaningful and virtuous life.

quotes.quote: I cannot teach anybody anything, I can only make them think.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that the role of the teacher was not to impart knowledge, but to encourage critical thinking and self-reflection in the student.

quotes.quote: I am not an Athenian or a Greek, but a citizen of the world.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that human beings shared a common humanity and that it was important to transcend national and cultural boundaries in the pursuit of wisdom and virtue.

quotes.quote: No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it's not the same river and he's not the same man.
quotes.history: This quote is from Heraclitus, who believed that everything in the universe was in a constant state of flux and that change was the only constant.

quotes.quote: There is nothing permanent except change.
quotes.history: This quote is from Heraclitus, who believed that the universe was constantly in a state of flux and that change was the only constant.

quotes.quote: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that the pursuit of wisdom was a never-ending process of questioning and self-examination, and that true wisdom involved recognizing the limits of one's own knowledge.

quotes.quote: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that excellence was not a one-time event, but rather the result of consistently practicing good habits and virtues.

quotes.quote: Man is the measure of all things.
quotes.history: This quote is from Protagoras, a Greek philosopher who believed that truth and morality were relative to individual human experience and perception.

quotes.quote: Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food.
quotes.history: This quote is from Hippocrates, a Greek physician who is often called the father of modern medicine. He believed that food was an essential component of good health and that proper nutrition could prevent and cure many diseases.

quotes.quote: We can easily forgive a child who is afraid of the dark; the real tragedy of life is when men are afraid of the light.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, a Greek philosopher who believed that fear and ignorance were the primary obstacles to achieving true knowledge and wisdom.

quotes.quote: Good people do not need laws to tell them to act responsibly, while bad people will find a way around the laws.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, who believed that laws were necessary to maintain social order, but that true morality and responsibility came from within.

quotes.quote: I know that I am intelligent, because I know that I know nothing.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that true wisdom came from recognizing the limits of one's own knowledge and the need for continuous questioning and self-examination.

quotes.quote: Happiness depends upon ourselves.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that happiness was the ultimate goal of human life and that it could only be achieved through cultivating virtues and living in harmony with others.

quotes.quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that self-examination and questioning were the key to achieving wisdom and leading a fulfilling life.

quotes.quote: I cannot teach anybody anything, I can only make them think.
quotes.history: This quote is from Socrates, who believed that true learning comes from within and that teachers can only help to guide their students towards their own understanding and insights.

quotes.quote: In war, the first casualty is the truth.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aeschylus, an ancient Greek playwright who wrote about the horrors and tragedies of war.

quotes.quote: It is not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
quotes.history: This quote is from Epictetus, a Greek philosopher who taught about the importance of maintaining a positive attitude and focusing on the things that are within our control.

quotes.quote: Wise men speak because they have something to say; fools because they have to say something.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, who believed that true wisdom comes from careful consideration and reflection, rather than impulsiveness or a desire for attention.

quotes.quote: Excellence is never an accident. It is always the result of high intention, sincere effort, and intelligent execution; it represents the wise choice of many alternatives - choice, not chance, determines your destiny.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that excellence was the result of deliberate, thoughtful action and that it required both effort and intelligence.

quotes.quote: To avoid criticism say nothing, do nothing, be nothing.

quotes.quote: Courage is the first of human qualities because it is the quality which guarantees the others.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that courage was the foundation for all other virtues and that it was essential for achieving personal success and happiness.

quotes.quote: Friendship is a single soul dwelling in two bodies.

quotes.quote: It is not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
quotes.history: This quote is from Epictetus, a Greek philosopher who believed that individuals could control their reactions to external events and that this control was essential for achieving personal happiness and success.

quotes.quote: Freedom is the only worthy goal in life. It is won by disregarding things that lie beyond our control.
quotes.history: This quote is from Epictetus, who believed that freedom was the ultimate goal of human life and that it could only be achieved by focusing on the things that were within one's control and ignoring the rest.

quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, who believed that leadership required both the ability to serve others and the skills necessary to lead effectively.

quotes.quote: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, who believed that power could reveal a person's true character and that it should be used wisely and responsibly.

quotes.quote: Ignorance, the root and stem of all evil.

quotes.quote: Education is the best provision for old age.

quotes.quote: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that intellectual curiosity and open-mindedness were necessary for personal growth and the pursuit of knowledge.

quotes.quote: There is only one way to avoid criticism: do nothing, say nothing, and be nothing.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that criticism was an inevitable part of life and that individuals should not fear it, but rather use it as an opportunity to learn and grow.

quotes.quote: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
quotes.history: This quote is from Plato, who believed that individuals should use their power and influence for the greater good, rather than for personal gain or selfish purposes.

quotes.quote: All men by nature desire knowledge.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that the pursuit of knowledge was a natural human instinct and that individuals should continually strive to learn and understand the world around them.

quotes.quote: Excellence is an art won by training and habituation. We do not act rightly because we have virtue or excellence, but we rather have those because we have acted rightly. We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act but a habit.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that excellence was achieved through practice and discipline, and that individuals should strive to continually improve themselves in order to achieve success and fulfillment in life.

quotes.quote: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.

quotes.quote: At the touch of love, everyone becomes a poet.

quotes.quote: The worst form of inequality is to try to make unequal things equal.
quotes.history: This quote is from Aristotle, who believed that true equality was achieved not by treating everyone the same, but by treating people according to their individual needs and circumstances.

quotes.quote: There is no harm in repeating a good thing.
